title: Willian Massami Watanabe - Curriculum
description: Willian Massami Watanabe is a Software Engineer at Yahoo! and Ph.D. candidate in Computer Sciences, who is specialized in the development of Web applications, making use of the great number of technologies now available. This webpage describes Willian's professional activities in a curriculum format.
keywords: Willian Massami Watanabe, curriculum, Web Developer, Front-end Web Engineer, Ajax, Web 2.0, Web usability, Web accessibility

introduction.headline: Front-end Web Engineer
introduction.paragraph: As a Software Engineer at Yahoo! and a Ph.D. candidate in Computer Sciences, is specialized in the development of Web applications, making use of the great number of technologies now available. Eager to contribute by developing quality assured Web applications, also considering attributes such as usability, maintenance and multi-platform characteristic of the Web.

paragraphs.paragraph: Information Technology professional experienced in the use of different technologies, with the objective of allowing rich interactions for users in the Web.

Specialist in the development of web services patterns of communication, that allow an optimized communication protocol between applications and provide resources to the implementations of complex projects.
Advanced knowledge in the area of computer interfaces design, with experience in the field of Web accessibility and usability issues.

Software enginner at Yahoo!. Brazil 2011.: working specifically on two applications: Meme and Profile. Continuous Integration (CI) and Continuous Deployment strategies demand constant effort, while keeping the quality of continous delivery of features in the Web. Exercising Test-Driven Design, eXtreme Programming, Scrumm practices and dealing with performance and scalability non-functional requirements in Web systems.

Ph.D. candidate CAPES Scholarship at São Paulo University - ICMC (Mathematics and Computer Science Institute). This research is financed by CAPES and works on the area of Web Accessibility, Web Usability, Web Engineering, MDD, RIA - Rich Internet Applications and Ajax. The Ph.D. project is being developed under the orientation of Prof. Dra. Renata Pontin de Mattos Fortes.

Brazil, 2008-2010: inserted at project PorSimples which was financed by FAPESP and Microsoft Research, was responsible by the integration of text processing operations and interface design of the Facilita. The Facilita is a web application that works as an assistive technology facilitating portuguese reading activities on web pages through the use of automatic text summarization and simplification techniques. Simple interactions, usability and accessibility issues are essential requirements to the Facilita implementation and are the main themes of the research. JavaScript and AJAX characteristics provide some of the key features of design's simplicity and usability in Facilita. The project was developed under orientation of Prof. Dra. Pyccuracy Accessibility Actions: The main objective of this project is to implement accessibility actions for the pyccuracy, web acceptance testing application. Pyccuracy makes use of natural language expressions to generate user stories and acceptance scenarios that are automatically run in the browser, evaluating the behaviour of all layers of a web application (server and client side-scripting). However pyccuracy still have not implemented actions that can be classified as accessible for disabled users like "tabbing navigation", focus possibility for interactive elements, landmarks and header navigation, among other actions. The goal of implementing accessibility actions for pyccuracy is to be able to execute acceptance tests of web applications functionality, considering disabled users task completion with assistive technologies. These users do no rely on the same visual and interactive mechanisms such as mouse and link colors, for example. So pyccuracy actions must consider these characteristics to guarantee that the functionality of the web application is available for all users. From the development perspective, accessibility actions drive automatic accessibility evaluation tools into a Continuous Integration environment. Making it possible to include accessibility non-functional requirements into the development life-cycle of projects and assisting developers while coding solutions for them.

Facilita: a web application that aims to automatically provide users with accessible content, through the use of text processing techniques (textual summarization and simplification). This application is being developed among with the PorSimples project. Simplicity of interaction and usability are some of the key features of this application. This application makes use of lots of Ajax Design patterns (like Cross-Domain Proxy, Fat Client, Multi-Stage Download, On-Demand Javascript) in order to provide the user with the best possible interaction. Facilita also makes use of distributed programming in order to deliver its functionality. The distributed programming is made with the use of multiple services which are integrated through RESTFul Service on the server side of the application. The installation and how to use tutorials are available on Facilita's page.

Educational Facilita: another web application that aims to automatically provide users with accessible textual content, through the use of Named Entities Recognition (automatically identifying proper nouns and others entities in the text) and Lexical Elaboration (providing users with simplier versions of the same word) techniques. The application identifies named entities in the text and then it provides the user with additional information about those entities. The additional informations are extracted from Wikipedia. The application also presents synonimous for words that are evaluated as complex or difficult to be understood. Educational Facilita was implemented as a Jetpack extension, and by doing so works as a browser plugin feature.

50 lines contest - Scale Tabs: Scale Tabs works as a browser extension that allows users find the browser tabs that they are looking for. This application was also developed using the Jetpack extension and makes use of the Browser layer of development in order to controll the tabs which are presented in the browser. It also uses Canvas in order to present snapshots of the tabs that are being accessed. This Firefox extension was implemented as part of the Jetpack 50 lines contest.

Scale Tabs: improved version of the 50 lines contest - Scale Tabs Jetpack addon. This addon release used the Addon-SDK (improved version and final release of the Jetpack prototype) and presents improved features (Address bar integration) and improved layout. Its source code is available in github.

YQL-Accessibility: YQL stands for Yahoo! Query Language, as a standard language for querying web resources. It presents a SQL-like syntax that enable queries to be made on RESTful webservices. YQL-Accessibility implements a set of tables (two for the moment) that allow these queries to be executed against web accessibility evaluation websites. It provides developers a simple way and unique way of identifying and reporting accessibility issues that are raised by automatic evaluation tools available in the Web.

NoRisk Planning: an interface prototype of an agenda like application for scheduling presentations of graduation projects in ICMC. This application uses the Dojo Toolkit in order to deliver rich UI Widgets within the interface and increment the usability and interaction of the interface. The presentations are offered to researches of the institute so that they can choose the topics and areas most familiar to them, with Adalberto Gonzaga Filho and Prof. Dra. Renata Pontin de Mattos Fortes.
